@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish I do ascribe to Stephen Porges’ polyvagal theory, which explains autonomic functions. Neuroception, for example protected humans from dying - that fight or flight response is an important one. A child in fear of a teacher is going to insecure, and neuroception is part of that.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish Complex behaviour is driven by bottom up neural communication. This is so important to understand. Top down communication is executive function. Executive function that is impaired will result in more emotional responses.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish I prefer that psychology play a major role - gauging feelings of child, first and foremost, because Russell Barkley says that emotions drive behaviour. Emotions drive children’s behaviour and it is the lack of understanding and empathy that creates meltdowns.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish not without the free will of the individual. Why do you think so many #autistics despise #ABA? For very good reasons, as the one thing that happens cognitively is the loss of control, violation of your own will. I will never recommend #PBS or #ABA.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish You can use behaviourism to establish something, but does it truly tell you what is going on cognitively. One of the criticisms of behaviourism is that it is too limited in scope. It eliminates the role of emotions. A behaviourist cannot change a person’s behaviour,

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish The situation of moralism versus ethical perspectives is an eye opener, as moralism is determined by familial & societal norms and values, which are superimposed on any idea of right or wrong. Behaviourism is looking at the behaviour itself, is missing the deeper origins.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish Ethical dilemmas are an interesting study on their own, however, what I learnt from ethics is to recognise your own perspective first, when looking at a question about ethics. You have to walk a fine line and know that you, being the evaluator can be wrong!

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish I have been doing a fair amount of reading about Behaviorism and I found it interesting, but I think the weak thing about behaviourism is that it excludes the person judging behaviour - the natural bias. I have studied ethics, which asks people to analyse situations.

@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish @GavinJHawkins @_FloPsych @Rogue_Soc_Psych And actually that is why it dehumanises human behaviour.
@StarlightMcKenz @VeeBookish @GavinJHawkins @_FloPsych @Rogue_Soc_Psych As I said, it does depend on your approach.

@pjshortland Ah. Thank you for clarifying.
@pjshortland And you have fight, flight or shutdown. All three responses trigger inappropriate behaviour.

@pjshortland Perhaps we should depart from having an overall general education to one that permits children in a far more narrow scope. The problem with forcing children to learn subjects they don’t enjoy and then enforce behaviouralism creates learning in fear, which engages the amygdala.

@pjshortland Education should not be about the storing of facts, and details learned through rote learning - by rather through engagement and development by engaging a child’s interests. If children enjoy learning, they will become accomplished at whatever interests they have.

@pjshortland Greene sees each child as unique, with a number of lagging skills and personal challenges to overcome. This view is where education should be headed. Educators should collaborate with each child to succeed. And this can and does happen with his CPS programme.

@pjshortland By virtue of Greene’s training he was intimately aware of behaviouralism, and chose to take a different approach, particularly with regards to neuroscience and neurology, understanding that not every child fits a mould (as much as the DfE would like).

@pjshortland However, I view the neoliberalist’s view on behaviouralism to be more dangerous than anything else. A whole generation of children are facing a less-than-positive future because of behaviouralism. Ross Greene turns behaviouralism on its head.

@pjshortland IMHO education in the U.K. is currently in trouble - in general. We have the Gove years to thank for that, and #SEND education is in bad shape. I am not familiar with the debate you refer to, and why you make the comment that the debate is dangerous.

@joshytheegaga @AskADHD Anyone with #ADHD or #autism can be classified as having a fragile nervous system. The fragile nervous system is finely attuned to sensory input, like noise at a certain frequency, your skin is sensitive to texture, smells etc. These can cause anxiety.

If I was called a liar, I would demand that the legal representative back up their statement. The hearing would stop until then. These solicitors and barristers working on behalf of LAs are as much part of the problem.

I believe that this would reduce legal wrangling by professionals. I also believe that these professionals should be held accountable directly to families. They should be able to be sued for malpractice. I am fuming tonight. A Barrister can call a Mom a liar, rhetorically.

IMHO, any hearing that includes a solicitor or barrister, should for the legal principle of fair justice, allow a family to appoint a solicitor or barrister at LA/State cost. This would prevent parents being “deer in the headlights” cannon fodder in any hearing.

Professionals dictate to parents, they use legal professionals to attack any parent that stands up to LAs, schools, doctors, nurses, teachers and social workers. Parents who dare show ire are accused of being “unreasonable”.

#SEND & #EHCP are professional driven, without regard to parents or child. This system is completely and utterly broken. #Childprotection is also professional driven. The parents are alone in their battle, against the resources of the State, and for that reason it is a mess.

@DopamineShark Childhood is experienced very differently between the two regions.  Asia is not a great place to have #ADHD - very low acceptance. This can cause immense trauma and emotional stunting.

@DopamineShark External environmental factors DO play a role in #ADHD, for sure! You are into something there. Social acceptance, customs, norms and values all play a role. For example, Southern Mediterranean countries are far more laid back to Northern European countries.
@DopamineShark The Limbic system over rides the prefrontal cortex and you don’t have control of your emotions. In #ADHD folks, this whole process is magnified 100 times.

@DopamineShark What affects us and triggers us, is the fragility of the nervous system, and neuroception is a primal autonomous function - it just kicks in - and that is where trauma and emotional response comes in. When you feel threatened, your neuroception triggers your limbic system.

Gove: “Our country is an unparalleled success story, but not everyone shares in it.”

There is that idea of British exceptionalism… 

Our country is far from an “unparalleled success”, when it treats our children like dirt! And discriminates against the disabled.

@DopamineShark The neurobiology of the #ADHD brain determines how #ADHD presents.  The executive function in the brain can be better developed in some folks, in others, not so much. Age also plays a role - under 30? Your brain is not fully developed.

@DopamineShark There will be variables within #ADHD - the neurobiology - means that it will present differently in different people. Then, there are comorbidities, that complicate #ADHD. #ADHD is much like #autism - a spectrum disorder - not in severity but ability.

It does no good to someone with #ADHD to find themselves in a job they hate. This is just a fact of #ADHD. 

I will be working on golf later this year and earning a lot of money in a short period of money. What needs to happen, is that we need to save the money I earn!

I have done this numerous times in the past. However, I have worked in television for 29 years and I love what I do.

I have found how emotionally damaging it is to work in something I am not able to do - if I have no interest, it is hard to motivate!

We have a good marriage and we are a good team, but we do have bust ups. 

The question of me being unwilling to take a part time job has my wife really angry, but unfortunately, I cannot do so, unless it is something that I have an interest in.

On Sunday I tweeted that I was feeling broken. I would like to thank my followers for their concern. 

Having #ADHD and being married to a spouse without #ADHD is extremely difficult, particularly if your spouse is possibly on the #autistic spectrum. I spent yesterday recovering.

@CommunityCare A child with #ADHD going into care will more than likely land up in prison, or homeless, pregnant, and they will be moved into permanent care homes, as foster carers are unable to cope. This is the fate that affects children with neuro developmental disorders.

@CommunityCare A child with #ADHD, who is removed and placed in care, drops into a void, and their needs are not met, they don’t get to see a CAMHS consultant regularly, are or become unmedicated. These children become unruly, uncontrollable or so traumatised.

@CommunityCare …is counter productive and will traumatise an autistic child and cause significant harm. The parents and siblings understand the needs and issues better than any foster carer will, or any carer in a home. The fact is that an autistic child is likely to be later sectioned.

@CommunityCare To remove a child with a neuro developmental disorder from their parents, simply because parents are asking for assistance in line with S17 of the CFA 1989, is a human rights violation and extreme discrimination. For example removing a child with autism from their family…

@RachelBurge8 The bottom up communication in the brain will always overwhelm the top down communication, which is why this “diagnosis” is a rubbish one. Sensory input, anxiety, frustration and all external stimuli can set off a chain reaction from the Limbic system.

@RachelBurge8 The Limbic system, neuroception, the cerebellum all play a part in behaviour. Emotions flooding the brain simply means that the prefrontal cortex is unable to function. Executive function is compromised. You cannot reason with an angry person who is a neuro divergent.

@RachelBurge8 Particularly with #ADHD, people can present with behaviour that is inappropriate for an adult of 48, but this also applies to people with #autism. Neuroscience and neurobiology have answers for unstable emotional behaviour! When is the psychiatry profession going to change?

@RachelBurge8 When behaviour is a form of communication and people with neuro disabilities have fragile nervous systems, this entire “diagnosis” is nonsensical, unscientific and unproven, except to speak of symptoms. It is much like the #ADHD acronym that is a diagnosis.

#Autistic children have a one way ticket to an ATU, and sectioning that may be for life. The fact is that these are vulnerable people. To remove them from their families for want of support under S17 of the CFA 1989 is a gross human rights violation!

#Autistic children NEED their families! Parents have cared for them from birth, will understand their needs. These children need close loving families that support them emotionally, understanding their behaviour. A corporate parent, or a foster carer cannot provide this care.

*Hyperfocusing on anything but what you need to do.

You have to realise how important it is to keep a good relationship. Sabotage is stupid. #ADHD does not also prevent stupidity. Our inability to consider consequences is a huge problem. Take it from me - keep the long term relationships. Cherish them. /11

Today, I have learnt hard lessons. Some I am still in the process of learning. #ADHD creates boredom and listlessness and can cause one to get bored of a relationship too. In marriage this can be fatal to the relationship. This is something I have come out of. /10

This is of course borne out by the fact that we do not want people to see mistakes. #ADHD is a large part of this - you fear disapproval. It is unfortunate and many people in my position do the same. /9

And of course emotional dysfunction is hardly a benefit in relationships! Trying to present our best side all the time in relationships also sabotages our relationships with people. I used to lie a lot to try and do this. /8

#ADHD is an emotional dysregulating disorder. When we are spoken to in an unpleasant manner, it triggers our amygdala and Limbic system which creates social deficits too. We lack the ability to effectively communicate. /7

I have explained to various people that is a way to communicate with me and others with deep emotional trauma: always communicate in a non threatening manner. Why? Because sensitive subjects require executive function. /6

The fact remains that most with #ADHD will experience the same as my own experiences. Being misunderstood is the worst for me. Even now, I have huge sensitivities towards how people speak to me. The emotional scarring that I have is deep. /5

I spent my life with loneliness. Friends came and went, and I damaged a lot of them myself. #ADHD is a social deficit disorder - there are many facets to that. I feel guilt at how I hurt people, but I also experienced a lot of pain at seeing friendship crumple. /4

3 months down the line we moved in together. And got married 15 months later. I was 30 when we married. We both had to learn about relationships and how to make them work. But it has not been smooth sailing. #ADHD has intruded on my relationship all too often. /3

My wife I suspect is on the #autistic spectrum, she is also introverted and has very few close friends. We are made for each other. She liked me - the first time a woman had shown true romantic feelings towards me. I asked her out and she said yes.

A thread on #ADHD and relationships. 

I am married, and grateful. Next year will be 20 years. I don’t know how we have managed it, but I know I have a wife that loves me. That is more than most with #ADHD will have. I know that.

I have had a lovely Christmas. We have had family with us and it has done us all good. 

I am feeling melancholic today, with a fair amount of anxiety. Emotions are difficult at times.
